author: Special Correspondent
text:
A delegation of Federation of Trade and Industries Association at the collectorate in Erode on Monday to submit a petition on Election Commission’s notification on cash and articles seized from traders. —PHOTO: M. GOVARTHAN

The Federation of All Trade and Industry Associations (FATIA) urged the District Collector and District Election Officer S. Prabakar on Monday seeking a temporary halt to the spot checks of traders by flying squads to rule out cash possession beyond the level specified by the Election Commission.

Such checks could be carried out closer to the election date, N. Sivanesan, FATIA president, said. There were difficulties in obtaining supporting documents for withdrawals immediately from the banks. Property registration warrants payment of large amounts of cash.

Textile and turmeric business has been hit due to the Election Commission’s norm on cash possession, and farmers were unable to purchase seeds or sell their cattle and livestock.

Marriage purchases have also been obstructed by the norm, Mr. Sivanesan said.

The petition called for permitting traders to have cash in their possession to an extent of Rs. 5 lakh.

Discounts were possible only when commodities were purchased in cash.

The flying squads, rather than confiscating the money they find in the possession or traders immediately, must check their background and verify their identity cards before proceeding with action. There must also be more clarity on what constitute supporting documents, Mr. Sivanesan said.
title: Traders want norms on cash possession relaxed
